title: Cuomo’s Political Self-Inoculation
sub_head: The New York Governor now wants people to take a vaccine he said they should be skeptical of.
body:
James Freeman is away and will return 12/8.

Cuomo, Trump and Vaccines: It’s Complicated
Maybe politicians shouldn’t be expected to keep consistent positions, but they also shouldn’t punish people who heed their advice before they change it. Take New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who in October said the American public “should be” skeptical of a Covid-19 vaccine approved by the Food and Drug Administration during the Trump presidency. He also promised to convene a state panel to review trial data before distributing shots to the public.
Then on Nov. 13 Mr. Cuomo accused President Trump of bullying him by saying “we won’t be delivering [a vaccine] to New York until we have [state] authorization to do so. . .Gov. Cuomo will have to let us know when he’s ready for it. Otherwise we can’t be delivering it to a state that won’t be giving it to its people.”
